title: Bounds for twisted symmetric square $L$-functions - III

title_detail.value: Bounds for twisted symmetric square $L$-functions - III

summary:
Let $f$ be a newform, and let $\chi$ be a primitive character of conductor
$q^{\ell}$. Assume that $q$ is an odd prime. In this paper we prove the
subconvex bound $$ L(\t1/2,\Sym f\otimes\chi)\ll_{f,q,\varepsilon}
q^{3\ell(1/4-1/36+\varepsilon)} $$ for any $\varepsilon>0$. This can be
compared with the recently established $t$-aspect subconvexity of the symmetric
square $L$-functions.

summary_detail.value:
Let $f$ be a newform, and let $\chi$ be a primitive character of conductor
$q^{\ell}$. Assume that $q$ is an odd prime. In this paper we prove the
subconvex bound $$ L(\t1/2,\Sym f\otimes\chi)\ll_{f,q,\varepsilon}
q^{3\ell(1/4-1/36+\varepsilon)} $$ for any $\varepsilon>0$. This can be
compared with the recently established $t$-aspect subconvexity of the symmetric
square $L$-functions.

author: Ritabrata Munshi
arxiv_comment: 12 pages. arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:1203.0749
fulltext:
BOUNDS FOR TWISTED SYMMETRIC SQUARE L-FUNCTIONS - III

arXiv:1205.1209v1 [math.NT] 6 May 2012

RITABRATA MUNSHI
Abstract. Let f be a newform, and let χ be a primitive character of conductor q l . Assume that q
is an odd prime. In this paper we prove the subconvex bound

1
1
L 21 , Sym2 f ⊗ χ ≪f,q,ε q 3l( 4 − 36 +ε)
for any ε > 0. This can be compared with the recently established t-aspect subconvexity of the
symmetric square L-functions.

1. Introduction
Let f be a newform of full level and weight k. Let χ be a primitive character of conductor M .
Then from the functional equation of L(s, Sym2 f ⊗ χ) and the convexity principle we get the bound

3
L 12 , Sym2 f ⊗ χ ≪f,ε M 4 +ε

for the central value. Getting a subconvex bound of the form M θ with θ < 3/4, in this context is
an intriguing open problem, which has recently attracted some attention. Blomer [1] has proved such
a subconvex bound for quadratic characters χ with prime modulus. In [6] we considered the case of
general (non-quadratic) characters with prime power modulus q l for any fixed l > 1. In particular for
χ primitive modulo q 3 (q prime) it was shown that

9
1
L 21 , Sym2 f ⊗ χ ≪k,ε q 4 − 4 +ε .

In the sequel [7] we used similar methods to prove subconvex bounds when the modulus of χ is squarefree with a suitably large prime factor. The purpose of the present paper, the third in the series, is to
prove the following
Theorem 1. Let f ∈ Sk (1) be a newform of full level and weight k. Let χ be a character of conductor
q l where q is an odd prime number. Then we have

3
1
L 12 , Sym2 f ⊗ χ ≪f,q,ε q 4 l− 12 l+lε .

The implied constant depends on f , q and ε, but does not depend on l.

Remark 1. In [7] we considered the case where l is fixed and q → ∞, and here we are looking at the
case where q is fixed and l → ∞.

Remark 2. From the adelic point of view, this result can be compared with the t-aspect subconvexity
result of Li [5] for the symmetric square L-function. Any (unitary) Hecke character Ψ on the idele
group
Y
×
A×
Z×
p
Q /Q = R+ ×
p

it

decomposes as Ψ = |.| ⊗ (⊗p ψp ) where t ∈ R, and ψf = ⊗p ψp corresponds to a Dirichlet character,

χ say. Then the twisted L-function L 12 , Sym2 f ⊗ Ψ corresponds to L 21 + it, Sym2 f ⊗ χ . Thus
Li [5] deals with the case of twists by Hecke characters which are 'supported' only at the prime at
infinity, and in the present case we are considering twists by Hecke characters which are 'supported'
(ramified) at a fixed finite prime q.
Acknowledgements. A part of this work was done while the author was enjoying the hospitality of the
Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata. The author also wishes to thank Peter Sarnak for suggesting
him to look at this aspect of subconvexity.
1991 Mathematics Subject Classification. 11F66, 11M41.
Key words and phrases. Symmetric square L-functions, subconvexity, twists.
1

RITABRATA MUNSHI

We conclude this section with an observation. Using integration-by-parts on Ir (n, m; c) and the
analytic properties of the Bessel function we get that we can basically ignore the contribution coming
from the terms in (8) with c large, e.g. c > Q = q 2012l , or from the terms in (9) with gcd(n, m) > Q.

5. Reciprocity and Poisson summation - II
In Section 4, we explicitly computed the character sum which appears in Lemma 3. Substituting
this explicit form of the character sum in (8), and ignoring the negligible contribution that comes
from the large values of c and the large values of the gcd (n, m) (as we have noted after Lemma 3),
we are basically left with the job of analysing sums of the type

(Here Q = q 2012l .) Recall that by our choice 2l − j ≥ 0.
The assumption on n and m, that they are ≡ 1 mod 4, is made to simplify some of the standard
complications related to the prime 2. In general we may take out the 2-primary part from n or m,
and then split the sum into four parts depending on the possible congruence classes modulo 4. Then
for each sum we follow the same steps that we take below. Also note that for notational simplicity
we are just focusing on the contribution from the nonnegative n and m.
Our next step is an application of the Poisson summation formula on the sum over c2 in (16). To
this end we have to first apply reciprocity

Proof. First using multiplicativity we reduce to the case where δ, u and v are powers of a given prime
p. Then we use well-known bounds for the Gauss sums and Ramanujan sums. Finally we need to
verify that the power of the prime p which appears on the right hand side is sufficiently large. For
this we need to consider several cases. We prefer to omit the details.
